question: Question_04_(d)
statement:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show
all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there.
Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Let

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{4}{\pi} \tan^{-1} x & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\
2-x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 
\end{cases}\end{align*}

NOTE: Another notation for \emph{tan}\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{x}) is
\emph{arctan}(\emph{x})

Determine open intervals where the graph of $f$ is concave upwards or
concave downwards, and the \emph{x}-coordinates of all inflection points
(if any).
sols:
To determine the intervals of concavity, we must evaluate $f''(x)$
and determine where it is positive and negative:

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{4}{\pi}\tan^{-1}(x) & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\
2 - x^{4} & \text{if } x < 1 
\end{cases}\end{align*} Evaluating the second derivative of f gives

\begin{align*}f''(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{4}{\pi}\frac{-2x}{(1 + x^{2})^{2}} & \text{if } x > 1 \\
-12x^{2} & \text{if } x < 1 
\end{cases}\end{align*} From this we see that the possible inflection points are
\emph{x} = 0. We need only confirm that the sign of the concavity
changes across \emph{x} = 0. We must also consider concavity changes
across \emph{x} = 1 since $f$ is not differentiable there.

When \emph{x} \textless{} 1, the second derivative is always negative
since -12\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} is always negative.

When \emph{x} \textgreater{} 1, the second derivative is always negative
as well since in that case, -2\emph{x} is always negative.

From these results we can see that $f(x)$ is concave down for all
\emph{x} except at the critical points. In other words, $f(x)$ is
concave down on $(-\infty,0),(0,1),(1,\infty)$ and so, there are no
inflection points.
hints: How does concavity relate to the derivatives of the function f(x)?
